label: __AtPrompt( <nRow>, <nCol>, <cPrompt>, [<xMsg>] ) --> .F.
documentation: Display a menu item on screen and define a message

arguments.label: <nRow>
arguments.documentation: is the row number to display the menu <cPrompt>. Value could range from zero to MaxRow().

arguments.label: <nCol>
arguments.documentation: is the column number to display the menu <cPrompt>. Value could range from zero to MaxCol().

arguments.label: <cPrompt>
arguments.documentation: is the menu item character string to display.

arguments.label: <xMsg>
arguments.documentation: define a message to display each time this menu item is highlighted. <xMsg> could be a character string or code block that is evaluated to a character string. If <xMsg> is not specified or of the wrong type, an empty string ("") would be used.

name: __AtPrompt

return.help: __AtPrompt() always return .F.

label: __dbCopyStruct( <cFileName>, [<aFieldList>] )
documentation: Create a new database based on current database structure

arguments.label: <cFileName>
arguments.documentation: is the name of the new database file to create. `.dbf` is the default extension if none is given.

arguments.label: <aFieldList>
arguments.documentation: is an array where each element is a field name. Names could be specified as uppercase or lowercase.

name: __dbCopyStruct

label: __dbCopyXStruct( <cFileName> ) --> lSuccess
documentation: Copy current database structure into a definition file

arguments.label: <cFileName>
arguments.documentation: is the name of target definition file to create. `.dbf` is the default extension if none is given.

name: __dbCopyXStruct

return.help: __dbCopyXStruct() returns .F. if no database is *used* in the current work-area, .T. on success, or a run-time error if the file create operation had failed.

label: __dbCreate( <cFileName>, [<cFileFrom>], [<cRDDName>], [<lNew>], [<cAlias>] ) --> lUsed
documentation: Create structure extended file or use one to create new file

arguments.label: <cFileName>
arguments.documentation: is the target file name to create and then open. `.dbf` is the default extension if none is given.

arguments.label: <cFileFrom>
arguments.documentation: is an optional structure extended file name from which the target file <cFileName> is going to be built. If omitted, a new empty structure extended file with the name <cFileName> is created and opened in the current work-area.

arguments.label: <cRDDName>
arguments.documentation: is RDD name to create target with. If omitted, the default RDD is used.

arguments.label: <lNew>
arguments.documentation: is an optional logical expression, (.T.) opens the target file name <cFileName> in the next available unused work-area and makes it the current work-area. (.F.) opens the target file in the current work-area. Default value is (.F.). The value of <lNew> is ignored if

arguments.label: <cFileFrom>
arguments.documentation: is not specified.

arguments.label: <cAlias>
arguments.documentation: is an optional alias to USE the target file with. If not specified, alias is based on the root name of <cFileName>.

name: __dbCreate

return.help: __dbCreate() returns (.T.) if there is database *used* in the current work-area (this might be the newly selected work-area), or (.F.) if there is no database *used*. Note that on success a (.T.) would be returned, but on failure you probably end up with a run-time error and not a (.F.) value.

label: __dbDelim( <lExport>, <xcFile>, [<xcDelim>], [<aFields>], [<bFor>], [<bWhile>], [<nNext>], [<nRecord>], <lRest>  )
documentation: Copies the contents of a database to a delimited text file or appends the contents of a delimited text file to a database.

arguments.label: <lExport>
arguments.documentation: If set to .T., copies records to a delimited file. If set to .F., append records from a delimited file.

arguments.label: <xcFile>
arguments.documentation: The name of the text file to copy to or append from. If a file extension is not specified, ".txt" is used by default.

arguments.label: <xcDelim>
arguments.documentation: Either the character to use as the character field delimiter (only the first character is used). or `"BLANK"` (not case sensitive), which eliminates the character field delimiters and sets the field separator to a single space instead of a comma.

arguments.label: <aFields>
arguments.documentation: An array of field names to limit the processing to. If not specified, or if empty, then all fields are processed.

arguments.label: <bFor>
arguments.documentation: An optional code block containing a FOR expression that will reduce the number of records to be processed.

arguments.label: <bWhile>
arguments.documentation: An optional code block containing a WHILE expression that will reduce the number of records to be processed.

arguments.label: <nNext>
arguments.documentation: If present, but nRecord is not present, specifies to process this number of records, starting with the current record. A value of 0 means to process no records.

arguments.label: <nRecord>
arguments.documentation: If present, specifies the only record to process. A value of 0 means to process no records. Overrides <nNext> and <lRest>.

arguments.label: <lRest>
arguments.documentation: If <lExport> is .T., then if <lRest> is set to .T. and there are no

arguments.label: <nRecord>
arguments.documentation: , <nNext>, or <bWhile> arguments, processes all records from current to last.

name: __dbDelim

label: __dbSDF( <lExport>, <xcFile>, [<aFields>], [<bFor>], [<bWhile>], [<nNext>], [<nRecord>], <lRest> )
documentation: Copies the contents of a database to an SDF text file or appends the contents of an SDF text file to a database.

arguments.label: <lExport>
arguments.documentation: If set to .T., copies records to an SDF file. If set to .F., append records from an SDF file.

arguments.label: <xcFile>
arguments.documentation: The name of the text file to copy to or append from. If a file extension is not specified, ".txt" is used by default.

arguments.label: <aFields>
arguments.documentation: An array of field names to limit the processing to. If not specified, or if empty, then all fields are processed.

arguments.label: <bFor>
arguments.documentation: An optional code block containing a FOR expression that will reduce the number of records to be processed.

arguments.label: <bWhile>
arguments.documentation: An optional code block containing a WHILE expression that will reduce the number of records to be processed.

arguments.label: <nNext>
arguments.documentation: If present, but <nRecord> is not present, specifies to process this number of records, starting with the current record. A value of 0 means to process no records.

arguments.label: <nRecord>
arguments.documentation: If present, specifies the only record to process. A value of 0 means to process no records. Overrides <nNext> and <lRest>.

arguments.label: <lRest>
arguments.documentation: If <lExport> is .T., then if <lRest> is set to .T. and there are no <nRecord>, <nNext>, or <bWhile> arguments, processes all records from current to last.

name: __dbSDF

label: __dbStructFilter( <aStruct>, [<aFieldList>] ) --> aStructFiltered
documentation: Filter a database structure array

arguments.label: <aStruct>
arguments.documentation: is a multidimensional array with database fields structure, which is usually the output from dbStruct(), where each array element has the following structure:

arguments.label: <table>
arguments.documentation: Position   Description    dbstruct.ch 1          cFieldName     DBS_NAME 2          cFieldType     DBS_TYPE 3          nFieldLength   DBS_LEN 4          nDecimals      DBS_DEC

arguments.label: <aFieldList>
arguments.documentation: is an array where each element is a field name. Names could be specified as uppercase or lowercase.

name: __dbStructFilter

return.help: __dbStructFilter() return a new multidimensional array where each element is in the same structure as the original <aStruct>, but the array is built according to the list of fields in <aFieldList>. If <aFieldList> is empty, __dbStructFilter() return reference to the original <aStruct> array.

label: __Dir( [<cFileMask>] ) --> NIL
documentation: Display listings of files

arguments.label: <cFileMask>
arguments.documentation: File mask to include in the function return. It could contain path and standard wildcard characters as supported by your OS (like * and ?). If <cFileMask> contains no path, then SET DEFAULT path is used to display files in the mask.

name: __Dir

return.help: __Dir() always returns NIL.

label: __FLedit( <aStruct>, [<aFieldList>] ) --> aStructFiltered
documentation: Filter a database structure array

arguments.label: <aStruct>
arguments.documentation: is a multidimensional array with database fields structure, which is usually the output from dbStruct(), where each array element has the following structure:

arguments.label: <table>
arguments.documentation: Position   Description    dbstruct.ch 1          cFieldName     DBS_NAME 2          cFieldType     DBS_TYPE 3          nFieldLength   DBS_LEN 4          nDecimals      DBS_DEC

arguments.label: <aFieldList>
arguments.documentation: is an array where each element is a field name. Names could be specified as uppercase or lowercase.

name: __FLedit

return.help: __FLedit() return a new multidimensional array where each element is in the same structure as the original <aStruct>, but the array is built according to the list of fields in <aFieldList>. If <aFieldList> is empty, __FLedit() return reference to the original <aStruct> array.

label: __mvRelease( <skeleton>, <include_exclude_flag> )
documentation: This function releases PRIVATE variables

arguments.label: <skeleton>
arguments.documentation: = string that contains the wildcard mask for variables' names that will be released. Supported wildcards: '*' and '?'

arguments.label: <include_exclude_flag>

documentation: If variable exists then returns its scope.

arguments.label: <cVarName>
arguments.documentation: = a string with a variable name to check

name: __mvScope

return.help: The symbolic values are defined in hbmemvar.ch HB_MV_NOT_FOUND variable is not declared (not found in symbol table) HB_MV_UNKNOWN if variable doesn't exist (but found in symbol table) HB_MV_ERROR if information cannot be obtained (memory error or argument error) HB_MV_PUBLIC for public variables HB_MV_PRIVATE_GLOBAL for private variables declared outside of current function/procedure HB_MV_PRIVATE_LOCAL for private variables declared in current function/procedure

label: __mvXRelease( <variable_name> )

arguments.label: <variable_name>

return.help: Nothing

label: AChoice( <nTop>, <nLeft>, <nBottom>, <nRight>, <acMenuItems>, [<alSelableItems> | <lSelableItems>], [<cUserFunction> | <bUserBlock>], [<nInitialItem>], [<nWindowRow>] ) --> nPosition
documentation: Allows selection of an element from an array

arguments.label: <nTop>
arguments.documentation: - topmost row used to display array (default 0)

arguments.label: <nLeft>
arguments.documentation: - leftmost row used to display array (default 0)

arguments.label: <nBottom>
arguments.documentation: - bottommost row used to display array (default MaxRow())

arguments.label: <nRight>
arguments.documentation: - rightmost row used to display array (default MaxCol())

arguments.label: <acMenuItems>
arguments.documentation: - the character array of items from which to select

arguments.label: <alSelableItems>
arguments.documentation: - an array of items, either logical or character, which is used to determine if a particular item may be selected.  If the type of a given item is character, it is macro evaluated, and the result is expected to be a logical.  A value of .T. means that the item may be selected, .F. that it may not. (See next argument: `lSelectableItems`)

arguments.label: <lSelableItems>
arguments.documentation: - a logical value which is used to apply to all items in `acMenuItems`.  If .T., all items may be selected; if .F., none may be selected. (See previous argument: `alSelectableItems`) Default .T.

arguments.label: <cUserFunction>
arguments.documentation: - the name of a function to be called which may affect special processing of keystrokes.  It is specified without parentheses or parameters. When it is called, it will be supplied with the parameters: `nMode`, `nCurElement`, and `nRowPos`. Default NIL.

arguments.label: <bUserBlock>
arguments.documentation: - a codeblock to be called which may affect special processing of keystrokes. It should be specified in the form `{| nMode, nCurElemenet, nRowPos | MyFunc( nMode, nCurElemenet, nRowPos ) }`. Default NIL.

arguments.label: <nInitialItem>
arguments.documentation: - the number of the element to be highlighted as the current item when the array is initially displayed.  1 origin.  Default 1.

arguments.label: <nWindowRow>
arguments.documentation: - the number of the window row on which the initial item is to be displayed. 0 origin.  Default 0.

name: AChoice

return.name: <nPosition>
return.help: - the number of the item to be selected, or 0 if the selection was aborted.

label: ACopy( <aSource>, <aTarget>, [<nStart>], [<nCount>], [<nTargetPos>] ) --> aTarget
documentation: Copy elements from one array to another

arguments.label: <aSource>

arguments.label: <nCount>

label: AddAscii( <[@]cString>, <nValue>, [<nPosition>], [<lCarryOver>] ) --> cString
documentation: Add an integer value to an ascii value of a string

arguments.label: <[@]cString>
arguments.documentation: is the string that should be edited

arguments.label: <nValue>
arguments.documentation: is a integer value that should be added to the ASCII value of the character at the <nPosition>th position [<nPosition>]  is the position of the character that should be edited. If not supplied, the last character of <[@]cString> is edited. [<lCarryOver>] NEW: is set to .T. if the substring from position 1 to position <nPosition> should be treated as an integer written to the base 256. Thus, the addition of <nValue> can affect to whole substring (see EXAMPLES). Default is .F., the original behaviour of this function.

name: AddAscii

return.help: The edited string is returned. The return value can be suppressed by using the CSetRef() function. The string must then be passed by reference [@].

label: AddMonth( [<dDate>,] <nMonths> ) -> dShiftedDate
documentation: add months to a date
name: AddMonth

label: ADel( <aArray>, <nPos> ) --> aArray
documentation: Delete an element from an array.

arguments.label: <aArray>
arguments.documentation: Name of array from which an element is to be removed.

arguments.label: <nPos>
arguments.documentation: Subscript of the element to be removed.

name: ADel

return.name: <aArray>
return.help: an array pointer reference.

label: ADir( [<cFileMask>], [<aName>], [<aSize>], [<aDate>], [<aTime>], [<aAttr>] ) --> nDirEntries
documentation: Fill pre-defined arrays with file/directory information

arguments.label: <cFileMask>
arguments.documentation: File mask to include in the function return. It could contain path and standard wildcard characters as supported by your OS (like * and ?). If you omit <cFileMask> or if <cFileMask> contains no path, then the path from SET DEFAULT is used.

arguments.label: <aName>
arguments.documentation: Array to fill with file name of files that meet <cFileMask>. Each element is a Character string and include the file name and extension without the path. The name is the long file name as reported by the OS and not necessarily the 8.3 uppercase name.

arguments.label: <aSize>
arguments.documentation: Array to fill with file size of files that meet <cFileMask>. Each element is a Numeric integer for the file size in Bytes. Directories are always zero in size.

arguments.label: <aDate>
arguments.documentation: Array to fill with file last modification date of files that meet <cFileMask>. Each element is of type Date.

arguments.label: <aTime>
arguments.documentation: Array to fill with file last modification time of files that meet <cFileMask>. Each element is a Character string in the format HH:mm:ss.

arguments.label: <aAttr>
arguments.documentation: Array to fill with attribute of files that meet <cFileMask>. Each element is a Character string, see Directory() for information about attribute values. If you pass array to <aAttr>, the function is going to return files with normal, hidden, system and directory attributes. If <aAttr> is not specified or with type other than Array, only files with normal attribute would return.

name: ADir

return.help: ADir() return the number of file entries that meet <cFileMask>

arguments.documentation: Can be either a single record number or an array of record numbers to add or delete from the AOF. If omitted, defaults to the current record.

arguments.label: <nType>
arguments.documentation: The type of operation:

arguments.label: <table-noheader>
arguments.documentation: ADS_AOF_ADD_RECORD      Add the record to the AOF (set the bit). This is the default operation. ADS_AOF_REMOVE_RECORD   Remove the record from the AOF (clear the bit). ADS_AOF_TOGGLE_RECORD   Switch the record into or out of the AOF.

return.name: <nError>

label: AdsKeyCount( [<xTag>], <cIgnoredIndexFile>, [<nFilterOption>] ) --> nKeyCount
documentation: Retrieve the number of keys in a specified index

arguments.label: <xTag>
arguments.documentation: Numeric order number OR index tag name. Default is current index.

arguments.label: <cIgnoredIndexFile>
arguments.documentation: This parameter is not processed. In other Harbour RDDs, the second parameter to "ordKeyCount" takes a second argument to identify a particular Index File in cases where two files are open that contain orders with the same name. The ADS driver does not support this and will select the first order with the requested name. To stay consistent with other RDDs, therefore, the second parameter is reserved and the

arguments.label: <nFilterOption>
arguments.documentation: is passed as a third parameter.

arguments.label: <nFilterOption>
arguments.documentation: Indicates if filters and/or scopes are to be respected if set. Options are defined in ads.ch:

arguments.label: <table-noheader>
arguments.documentation: ADS_RESPECTFILTERS   Respect filters and scopes ADS_IGNOREFILTERS    Ignore filters and scopes ADS_RESPECTSCOPES    Respect scopes only

name: AdsKeyCount

return.name: <nKeyCount>
return.help: The number of keys within the current index.

label: AdsKeyNo( [<xTag>], <cIgnoredIndexFile>, [<nFilterOption>] ) --> nKeyNo
documentation: Get the logical key number of the current record in the given index

arguments.label: <xTag>
arguments.documentation: Numeric order number OR index tag name. Default is current index.

arguments.label: <cIgnoredIndexFile>
arguments.documentation: This parameter is not processed. In other Harbour RDDs, the second parameter to "ordKeyNo" takes a second argument to identify a particular Index File in cases where two files are open that contain orders with the same name. The ADS driver does not support this and will select the first order with the requested name. To stay consistent with other RDDs, therefore, the second parameter is reserved and the

arguments.label: <nFilterOption>
arguments.documentation: is passed as a third parameter.

arguments.label: <nFilterOption>
arguments.documentation: Indicates if filters and/or scopes are to be respected if set. Options are defined in ads.ch:

arguments.label: <table-noheader>
arguments.documentation: ADS_RESPECTFILTERS   Respect filters and scopes ADS_IGNOREFILTERS    Ignore filters and scopes ADS_RESPECTSCOPES    Respect scopes only

name: AdsKeyNo

return.name: <nKeyNo>
return.help: The logical key number of the current record in the given index.

label: Alert( <xMessage>, [<aOptions>], [<cColorNorm>], [<nDelay>] ) --> nChoice or NIL
documentation: Display a dialog box with a message

arguments.label: <xMessage>
arguments.documentation: Message to display in the dialog box. <xMessage> can be of any Harbour type. If <xMessage> is an array of Character strings, each element would be displayed in a new line. If <xMessage> is a Character string, you could split the message to several lines by placing a semicolon `;` in the desired places.

arguments.label: <aOptions>
arguments.documentation: Array with available response. Each element should be Character string. If omitted, default is `{ "Ok" }`.

arguments.label: <cColorNorm>
arguments.documentation: Color string to paint the dialog box with. If omitted, default color is `"W+/R"`.

arguments.label: <nDelay>
arguments.documentation: Number of seconds to wait to user response before abort. Default value is 0, that wait forever.

name: Alert

return.help: Alert() return Numeric value representing option number chosen. If <Esc> was pressed, return value is zero. The return value is NIL if Alert() is called with no parameters, or if <xMessage> type is not Character and HB_CLP_STRICT option was used. If <nDelay> seconds had passed without user response, the return value is 1.

label: AtToken( <cString>, [<cTokenizer>], [<nTokenCount>], [<nSkipWidth>] ) -> nPosition

arguments.documentation: is the processed string [<cTokenizer>]     is a list of characters separating the tokens in <cString> Default: Chr( 0 ) + Chr( 9 ) + Chr( 10 ) + Chr( 13 ) + Chr( 26 ) + hb_BChar( 138 ) + hb_BChar( 141 ) + Chr( 32 ) + ",.;:!\?/\\<>()#&%+-*" [<nTokenCount>]    specifies the count of the token whose position should be calculated Default: last token [<nSkipWidth>]     specifies the maximum number of successive tokenizing characters that are combined as ONE token stop, e.g. specifying 1 can yield to empty tokens Default: 0, any number of successive tokenizing characters are combined as ONE token stop

label: dbEdit( [<nTop>], [<nLeft>], [<nBottom>], [<nRight>], [<acColumns>], [<xUserFunc>], [<xColumnSayPictures>], [<xColumnHeaders>], [<xHeadingSeparators>], [<xColumnSeparators>], [<xFootingSeparators>], [<xColumnFootings>] ) --> lOk
documentation: Browse records in a table

arguments.label: <nTop>
arguments.documentation: coordinate for top row display. <nTop> could range from 0 to MaxRow(), default is 0.

arguments.label: <nLeft>
arguments.documentation: coordinate for left column display. <nLeft> could range from 0 to MaxCol(), default is 0.

arguments.label: <nBottom>
arguments.documentation: coordinate for bottom row display. <nBottom> could range from 0 to MaxRow(), default is MaxRow().

arguments.label: <nRight>
arguments.documentation: coordinate for right column display. <nRight> could range from 0 to MaxCol(), default is MaxCol().

arguments.label: <acColumns>
arguments.documentation: is an array of character expressions that contain database fields names or expressions to display in each column. If not specified, the default is to display all fields from the database in the current work area.

arguments.label: <xUserFunc>
arguments.documentation: is a name of a user defined function or a code block that would be called every time unrecognized key is been pressed or when there are no keys waiting to be processed and dbEdit() goes into idle mode. If <xUserFunc> is a character string, it must contain root name of a valid user define function without parentheses. Both the user define function or the code block should accept two parameters: <nMode>, <nCurrentColumn>. Both should return a numeric value that correspond to one of the expected return codes (see table below for a list of <nMode> and return codes).

arguments.label: <xColumnSayPictures>
arguments.documentation: is an optional picture. If <xColumnSayPictures> is a character string, all columns would used this value as a picture string. If <xColumnSayPictures> is an array, each element should be a character string that correspond to a picture string for the column with the same index. Look at the help for `@...SAY` to get more information about picture values.

arguments.label: <xColumnHeaders>
arguments.documentation: contain the header titles for each column, if this is a character string, all columns would have that same header, if this is an array, each element is a character string that contain the header title for one column. Header may be split to more than one line by placing semicolon `;` in places where you want to break line. If omitted, the default value for each column header is taken from <acColumns> or field name if <acColumns> was not specified.

arguments.label: <xHeadingSeparators>
arguments.documentation: is an array that contain characters that draw the lines separating the headers and the fields data. Instead of an array you can use a character string that would be used to display the same line for all fields. Default value is a double line.

arguments.label: <xColumnSeparators>
arguments.documentation: is an array that contain characters that draw the lines separating displayed columns. Instead of an array you can use a character string that would be used to display the same line for all fields. Default value is a single line.

arguments.label: <xFootingSeparators>
arguments.documentation: is an array that contain characters that draw the lines separating the fields data area and the footing area. Instead of an array you can use a character string that would be used to display the same line for all footers. Default is to have to no footing separators.

arguments.label: <xColumnFootings>
arguments.documentation: contain the footing to be displayed at the bottom of each column, if this is a character string, all columns would have that same footer, if this is an array, each element is a character string that contain the footer for one column. Footer may be split to more than one line by placing semicolon `;` in places where you want to break line. If omitted, no footer are displayed.

name: dbEdit

return.help: dbEdit() return .F. if there is no database in use or if the number of columns to display is zero, else dbEdit() return .T.

label: ft_Blink( <cMsg>, [ <nRow> ], [ <nCol> ] ) -> NIL
documentation: Display a blinking message on the screen

arguments.label: <cMsg>
arguments.documentation: is the string to blink.

arguments.label: <nRow>
arguments.documentation: is an optional screen row for @...SAY, default current.

arguments.label: <nCol>
arguments.documentation: is an optional screen col for @...say, default current.

name: ft_Blink

return.help: NIL

label: ft_BrwsWhl( <aFields>, <bWhileCond>, <cKey>,                  ; [ <nFreeze> ], [ <lSaveScrn> ], [ <cColorList> ], ; [ <cColorShadow> ], [ <nTop> ], [ <nLeft> ],      ; [ <nBottom> ], [ <nRight> ] -> nRecno
documentation: Browse an indexed database limited to a while condition

arguments.label: <aFields>
arguments.documentation: is array of field blocks of fields you want to display. Example to set up last name and first name in array: aFields := {} AAdd( aFields, { "Last Name" , {|| Names->Last }  } ) AAdd( aFields, { "First Name", {|| Names->First } } )

arguments.label: <bWhileCond>
arguments.documentation: is the limiting WHILE condition as a block. Example 1: {|| Names->Last == "JONES" } Example 2: {|| Names->Last == "JONES" .AND. Names->First == "A"  }

arguments.label: <cKey>
arguments.documentation: is the key to find top condition of WHILE. cLast  := "JONES     " cFirst := "A" Example 1: cKey := cLast Example 2: cKey := cLast + cFirst

arguments.label: <nFreeze>
arguments.documentation: is number of fields to freeze in TBrowse.  Defaults to 0 if not passed.

arguments.label: <lSaveScrn>
arguments.documentation: is a logical indicating whether or not you want to save the screen from the calling program.  Defaults to .T. if not passed.

arguments.label: <cColorList>
arguments.documentation: is a list of colors for the TBrowse columns. The 1st color is used as SAY/TBrowse Background and the 3rd and 4th colors are used as part of column:defColor := { 3, 4 } Thus if you pass a cColorList, you MUST pass at least 4 colors. Defaults to "N/W, N/BG, B/W, B/BG, B/W, B/BG, R/W, B/R" if not passed.

arguments.label: <cColorShad>
arguments.documentation: is the color of the TBrowse box shadow.  Defaults to "N/N" if not passed.

arguments.label: <nTop>
arguments.documentation: , <nLeft>, <nBottom>, <nRight> are the coordinates of the area to display the TBrowse in.  Defaults to 2, 2, MaxRow() - 2, MaxCol() - 2 with shadowed box, i.e. full screen.

name: ft_BrwsWhl

return.help: nRecno is the number of the record selected by the <Enter> key. 0 is returned if there are either no records matching the WHILE condition or an <Esc> is pressed instead of an <Enter>

label: ft_Calendar( [ <nRow> ], [ <nCol> ], [ <cColor> ], [ <lShadow> ] , [ <lShowHelp> ] ) -> aRetVal
documentation: Display date/time calendar, find a date, return calendar data.

arguments.label: <nRow>
arguments.documentation: is an optional screen row for calendar display, default row 1.

arguments.label: <nCol>
arguments.documentation: is an optional screen col for calendar display, default col 63.

arguments.label: <cColor>
arguments.documentation: is an optional color string for displayed messages, default is bright white text over green background.

arguments.label: <lShadow>
arguments.documentation: is an optional logical variable. If true (.T.), it uses ft_Shadow() to add a transparent shadow to the display, default (.F.).

arguments.label: <lShowHelp>
arguments.documentation: is an optional logical variable. If true, uses ft_XBox() to display  a four line help message if the F1 key is pressed, default (.F.).

name: ft_Calendar

return.help: aRetVal  is an 8 element array containing date, month, day, year, month (in character format), day of the week, julian day and current time.

name: ft_CapLock

return.help: .T. if CapLock is set, .F. if it isn't set.  The value returned represents the setting in effect prior to any changes that might by made by <lNewSetting>.

label: ft_ClrSel( <aClrData>, [ <lClrMode> ], [ <cTestChr> ]  -> aClrData
documentation: User Selectable Color Routine

arguments.label: <aClrData>
arguments.documentation: is an array of subarrays, with each subarray containing information about the color settings. The subarray has the following structure: [ 1 ] cName    is the name of this color setting i.e. "Pick List" Maximum length is 20 bytes [ 2 ] cClrStr  is the current color string Default is "W/N,N/W,N/N,N/N,N/W" If Setting type is "M" (Menu) the colors are... 1.  Prompt Color 2.  Message Color 3.  HotKey Color 4.  LightBar Color 5.  LightBar HotKey Color Note: While there are many ways to code the individual color combinations,  they should be in the same format that gets returned from SetColor(), so the defaults can be found in the color palette. foreground [+] / background [*] i.e. "GR+/BG*, N/W*, N+/N, , W/N" [ 3 ] cType  is the type of color setting Default is "W" (Window) T = Title     Only 1 color element D = Desktop   Background color and character M = Menu      For ft_MenuTo() style menus W = Window    Windows with radio buttons G = Get       For use with @ SAY... B = Browse    For TBrowse() and *dbEdit() A = aChoice   Pick-lists etc... W/G/B/A are functionally the same but will provide a more appropriate test display. [ 4 ] cFillChar  is the character (for desktop background only) Default is ""

arguments.label: <lClrMode>
arguments.documentation: .T.  use color palette .F.  use monochrome palette Default is the IsColor() setting

arguments.label: <cTestChr>
arguments.documentation: 2 Byte character string for color test display Default is ""

name: ft_ClrSel

return.help: An array identical to the one passed, with new selected colors

label: ft_CLS( <nTRow>, <nLCol>, <nBRow>, <nRCol>, <nColor> ) -> NIL

label: ft_DateCnfg( [ <cFYStart> ], [ <nDow> ] ) -> aDateInfo
documentation: Set beginning of year/week for ft_*() date functions

arguments.label: <cFYStart>
arguments.documentation: is a character date string in the user's system date format, i.e., the same as the user would enter for CToD().  If this argument is NIL, the current value is unchanged. Note: The year portion of the date string must be present and be a valid year; however, it has no real meaning.

arguments.label: <nDow>
arguments.documentation: is a number from 1 to 7 (1 = Sunday) indicating the desired start of a work week.  If this argument is NIL, the current value is unchanged.

name: ft_DateCnfg

return.help: A 2-element array containing the following information: aDateInfo[ 1 ] - an ANSI date string indicating the beginning date of the year.  Only the month and day are meaningful. aDateInfo[ 2 ] - the number of the first day of the week (1 = Sunday)

label: ft_DayOfYr( [ <dGivenDate> ], [ <nDayNum> ], [ <lIsAcct> ] ) -> aDateInfo
documentation: Return calendar, fiscal or accounting day data

arguments.label: <dGivenDate>
arguments.documentation: is any valid date in any valid format.  Defaults to current system date if not supplied.

arguments.label: <nDayNum>
arguments.documentation: is a number from 1 to 371, signifying a day of a year. Defaults to current day if not supplied.

arguments.label: <lIsAcct>
arguments.documentation: is a logical which specifies the type of year to base the return value on:  .F. = calendar or fiscal year, .T. = accounting year.

name: ft_DayOfYr

return.help: A three element array containing the following data: If <nDayNum> is specified: aDateInfo[ 1 ] - The date of the specified day number aDateInfo[ 2 ] - The beginning date of the year aDateInfo[ 3 ] - The ending date of the year If <nDayNum> is not specified: aDateInfo[ 1 ] - The year and day as a character string "YYYYDDD" aDateInfo[ 2 ] - The beginning date of the year aDateInfo[ 3 ] - The ending date of the year

label: ft_DayToBoW( [ <dGivenDate> ] ) -> nDays
documentation: Calculate no. of days between date and beginning of week

arguments.label: <dGivenDate>
arguments.documentation: is any valid date in any valid date format. Defaults to current date if not supplied.

name: ft_DayToBoW

return.help: A positive number of days to beginning of week, range 0 to 6.

This allows you to make sure you specified a valid drive (i.e. if you attempt to change the default drive, and the function returns a different drive letter than the one you specified, then the drive does not exist).

label: ft_DispMsg( <aMessageArray>, [ <cKey2Check> ], [ <nTopBoxRow> ], [ <nLeftBoxColumn> ], [ <cnBoxType> ], [ <lShadow> ] ) -> lKeyMatch
documentation: Display a message and optionally waits for a keypress

arguments.label: <aMessageArray>
arguments.documentation: is a multidimensional array of messages to be displayed and the color attributes for each message. The first dimension of the array contains one or more elements, each representing one line in the message box, up to the maximum number of rows on the screen. Within each line of the message individual characters or groups of characters may be delimited with braces ([]).  The braces will be stripped out and the character(s) inside those braces will be highlighted. The second dimension of the array contains a color attribute for the corresponding element in dimension one, plus one additional element for the color of the box border.  Dimension two will always contain one more element than dimension one.  If an attribute is omitted, the last color selected will be used.

arguments.label: <Key2Check>
arguments.documentation: is a character string of one or more keys to check for.  If omitted, the message is displayed and control is returned to the calling procedure.  If one character is specified, ft_DispMsg() waits for one keypress, restores the screen and returns.  If multiple characters are specified, ft_DispMsg() remains in a loop until one of the specified keys has been pressed, then restores the screen and returns.

arguments.label: <nTopBoxRow>
arguments.documentation: is the upper row for the message box.  If omitted, the box is centered vertically.

arguments.label: <nLeftBoxColumn>
arguments.documentation: is the leftmost column for the box.  If omitted, the box is centered horizontally.

arguments.label: <cnBoxType>
arguments.documentation: is a string of characters or a variable for the box border.  See the DispBox() function.  If omitted, a double box is drawn.

arguments.label: <lShadow>
arguments.documentation: is a logical variable.  If true (.T.) or omitted, it uses ft_Shadow() to add a transparent shadow to the box.  If false (.F.), the box is drawn without the shadow.

name: ft_DispMsg

return.help: If <Key2Check> is not specified, ft_DispMsg() will return false (.F.). If <Key2Check> is a one-character string, ft_DispMsg() will return true (.T.) if the user presses that key, or false (.F.) if any other key is pressed. If <Key2Check> consists of multiple characters, it will lock the user in a loop until one of those keys are pressed and return the Inkey() value of the keypress.

return.help: The current selected text file area.

label: ft_FSkip( [ <nLines> ] ) -> nLinesSkipped
documentation: Move the record pointer to a new position in a text file

arguments.label: <nLines>
arguments.documentation: is the number of lines to skip.  Defaults to 1 if not specified.

name: ft_FSkip

return.help: The number of lines actually skipped.  If the file's EOF or BOF was encountered before ^b<nLines>^n could be skipped, the return value will be less than ^b<nLines>^n.

label: ft_FUse( [ <cFile> ] [, <nMode> ] ) -> nHandle | 0
documentation: Open or close a text file for use by the ft_F*() functions
name: ft_FUse

return.help: If ^b<cFile>^n is passed and the file is opened successfully, an integer containing the text file's workarea.  If the file cannot be opened, F_ERROR (-1) will be returned.  In this case, check the return value of ^bft_FError()^n for the cause of the error. If ft_FUse() is called without any arguments, it will close the text file in the current "text area" and return 0. If a read error occurs ^ft_FError()^n will contain the error code.

label: ft_FWriteLn( <cData>, [ <lInsert> ] ) -> lSuccess
documentation: Write a line to the currently selected text file

arguments.label: <cData>
arguments.documentation: is a string of data to write to the file at the current record position.

arguments.label: <lInsert>
arguments.documentation: is a logical indicating whether the contents of the current record are to be preserved, that is, if lInsert evaluates to .T., the a new record is inserted at the current position.  The current record then is pushed down to ft_FRecNo()+1. If lInsert is .F. or omitted, the current record is replaced by cData.

name: ft_FWriteLn

return.help: TRUE if successful, otherwise check ^ft_FError()^n for error code.

label: ft_GCD( <nNumber1>, <nNumber2> ) -> nGCD
documentation: Calculate greatest common divisor of two numbers

arguments.label: <nNumber1>
arguments.documentation: is the first number to find the GCD of.

arguments.label: <nNumber2>
arguments.documentation: is the second number to find the GCD of.

name: ft_GCD

return.help: The greatest common divisor of the 2 numbers, or 0 if either is 0.

label: ft_GetE( [ @<xReceiveVar> ] ) -> nNumStrings
documentation: Return the entire current environment

arguments.label: <xReceiveVar>
arguments.documentation: is the variable to receive the environment data.

arguments.label: <xReceiveVar>
arguments.documentation: can be a character type variable, in which case the function will place all environment strings in the variable separated by carriage return/line feeds (Chr( 13 ) + Chr( 10 )).

arguments.label: <xReceiveVar>
arguments.documentation: can be an array type, in which case the function will place each string in an array element.  The array MUST be declared with the proper number of elements prior to passing it to the function.  This can be done by calling ft_GetE() without parameters first to get the number of strings in the environment. Note that the argument MUST be passed by reference. Since arrays are by nature passed by reference, the "@" symbol is optional when passing an array. If no argument is passed, ft_GetE() merely returns the number of strings in the environment.

name: ft_GetE

return.help: ft_GetE() returns the total number of strings found in the current program's environment.

label: ft_GetMode() -> nVMode
documentation: Get the video mode
name: ft_GetMode

return.help: The video mode, as a numeric.

label: ft_GetVCur( [<nPage>] ) -> <aCurInfo>
documentation: Return info about the cursor on a specified video page

arguments.label: <nPage>
arguments.documentation: is the video page to get the cursor information for. Defaults to the current page, as returned by ft_GetVPg().

name: ft_GetVCur

return.help: A four-element array (<aCurInfo>), set up as follows: aCurInfo[ 1 ] = Top line of cursor aCurInfo[ 2 ] = Bottom line of cursor aCurInfo[ 3 ] = Character row aCurInfo[ 4 ] = Character column

label: ft_GetVPg() -> <nPage>
documentation: Get the currently selected video page
name: ft_GetVPg

return.help: The video page, as a numeric.

label: ft_Hex2Dec( <cHexNum> ) -> nDecNum
documentation: Convert a hex number to decimal

arguments.label: <cHexNum>
arguments.documentation: is a character string representing a hex number.

name: ft_Hex2Dec

return.help: A decimal number.

label: ft_IAmIdle() -> lSuccess
documentation: Inform the operating system that the application is idle.
name: ft_IAmIdle

return.help: .T. if supported, .F. otherwise.

label: ft_Idle()
documentation: Generate an idle event to allow incremental garbage collection.
name: ft_Idle

return.help: NIL

label: ft_inp( <nPort> ) -> nValue
documentation: Retrieve a byte from a specified I/O port

arguments.label: <nPort>
arguments.documentation: is the port from which to retrieve the byte.  If it is invalid in any way, the function will return zero.

name: ft_inp

return.help: The byte retrieved.

label: ft_int86( <nInterruptNumber>, <aRegisterValues> ) -> lResult
documentation: Execute a software interrupt

arguments.label: <nInterruptNumber>
arguments.documentation: is the interrupt to execute.

arguments.label: <aRegisterValues>
arguments.documentation: is an array that contains values to be loaded into the various CPU registers.  The correspondence between registers and array elements is as follows: aElement[ 1 ]  ==  AX register aElement[ 2 ]  ==  BX register aElement[ 3 ]  ==  CX register aElement[ 4 ]  ==  DX register aElement[ 5 ]  ==  SI register aElement[ 6 ]  ==  DI register aElement[ 7 ]  ==  BP register aElement[ 8 ]  ==  DS register aElement[ 9 ]  ==  ES register aElement[ 10 ] ==  Flags register

name: ft_int86

return.help: .T. if all parameters valid and the function was able to execute the desired interrupt. .F. if invalid parameters passed.  If you call this function in protected mode, .F. may also be returned if an allocation of low DOS memory fails. n addition, the array elements will contain whatever values were in he CPU registers immediately after the interrupt was executed.  If ither of the string parameters were altered by the interrupt, these hanges will be reflected as well.

label: ft_InvClr( [ <cDsrdColor> ] ) -> cColor
documentation: Get the inverse of a color

arguments.label: <cDsrdColor>
arguments.documentation: is the color to get the inverse of.  Defaults to current color.

name: ft_InvClr

return.help: The inverse of the passed color.

label: ft_IsBit( <cByte>, <nBitPos> ) -> lResult
documentation: Test the status of an individual bit

arguments.label: <cByte>
arguments.documentation: is a character from hb_BChar( 0 ) to hb_BChar( 255 ).

arguments.label: <nBitPos>
arguments.documentation: is a number from 0 to 7 conforming to standard right-to-left bit-numbering convention and representing the position of the bit within the byte.

name: ft_IsBit

return.help: .T. if designated bit is set (1), .F. if not set (0), NIL if invalid parameters.

label: ft_IsBitOn( <nNumber>, <nBit> ) -> lResult
documentation: Determine the state of individual bits in a number

arguments.label: <nNumber>
arguments.documentation: is an integer for which a bit state needs to be checked.

arguments.label: <nBit>
arguments.documentation: is a number from 0 to 15 that indicates which bit to test.

name: ft_IsBitOn

return.help: .T. if the specified bit was on., .F. if off.

label: ft_IsPrint( [ <cDevice> ] ) -> lResult
documentation: Check printer status

arguments.label: <cDevice>
arguments.documentation: is optional and is the device to test (LPT2, COM1, etc.). If omitted, the function will default to the PRN device.

name: ft_IsPrint

return.help: .T.  if device is ready for output. .F.  if one of the following conditions occurs: 1)  The device is not ready. 2)  The device does not exist. 3)  DOS couldn't open the device for some reason (such as no file handles available).

label: ft_IsShare() -> nRetCode
documentation: Determine if DOS "Share" is installed
name: ft_IsShare

return.help: nRetcode will be set as follows on exit: 0 if SHARE not loaded but ok to load 1 if SHARE not loaded and not ok to load 255 if SHARE loaded

label: ft_LastKey( <nKey> ) -> NIL
documentation: Force LastKey() to return a programmer-defined value.

arguments.label: <nKey>
arguments.documentation: is the Inkey() value of the desired key.

name: ft_LastKey

return.help: NIL

label: ft_LastKey( <nKey> ) -> NIL
documentation: Force LastKey() to return a programmer-defined value.

arguments.label: <nKey>
arguments.documentation: is the Inkey() value of the desired key.

name: ft_LastKey

return.help: NIL

label: ft_LDay( [ <dDateToChk> ] ) -> dLastDay
documentation: Return last day of the month

arguments.label: <dDateToChk>
arguments.documentation: is a date within a month for which you want to find the last date of that month.  If not passed or is an incorrect type, defaults to current system date.

name: ft_LDay

return.help: A Clipper date value representing the last date of the month.

label: ft_Linked( <cString> ) -> lResult
documentation: Determine if a function was linked in

arguments.label: <cString>
arguments.documentation: is a character string containing one or more function calls

name: ft_Linked

return.help: .T. if all functions within the string are currently linked into the application, .F. if one or more aren't.  See below for a definition of "function."

label: ft_MAdd( [ <dGivenDate> ], [ <nAddMonths> ], [ <lMakeEOM> ] ) -> dDate
documentation: Add or subtract months to/from a date

arguments.label: <dGivenDate>
arguments.documentation: is any valid date in any date format. Defaults to current system date if not supplied.

arguments.label: <nAddMonths>
arguments.documentation: is the number of months to be added or subtracted. Defaults to 0 if not supplied.

arguments.label: <lMakeEOM>
arguments.documentation: is a logical variable indicating whether or not to force the returned date to the last date of the month.  It only affects the returned date if <dGivenDate> is an end-of-month date.

name: ft_MAdd

return.help: A date.

label: ft_MButPrs( <nButton> [, @nButPrs [, @nX [, @nY] ] ] ) -> nButStatus
documentation: Retrieve button press status

arguments.label: <nButton>
arguments.documentation: is the mouse button number: 0 - Left   Button 1 - Right  Button 2 - Middle Button [if applicable]

arguments.label: <nButPrs>
arguments.documentation: is the number of times the specified button was pressed since the last call to this routine. PASSED BY REFERENCE.

arguments.label: <nX>
arguments.documentation: is the X position of the cursor when the last press occurred. PASSED BY REFERENCE.

arguments.label: <nY>
arguments.documentation: is the Y position of the cursor when the last press occurred. PASSED BY REFERENCE.

name: ft_MButPrs

return.help: An integer representing the button status: 0 - no buttons pressed 1 - left button pressed 2 - right button pressed 3 - left and right pressed 4 - middle pressed 5 - left and middle pressed 6 - middle and right buttons pressed 7 - all 3 buttons pressed

label: ft_MButRel( nButton [, @nButRel [, @nX [, @nY] ] ]) -> nBStat
documentation: Get mouse button release information

arguments.label: <nButton>
arguments.documentation: is the mouse button number 0 - Left   Button 1 - Right  Button 2 - Middle Button [if applicable]

arguments.label: <nButRel>
arguments.documentation: is the number of times the specified button was released since the last call to this routine. PASSED BY REFERENCE.

arguments.label: <nX>
arguments.documentation: is the X position of the cursor when the last release occurred. PASSED BY REFERENCE.

arguments.label: <nY>
arguments.documentation: is the Y position of the cursor when the last release occurred. PASSED BY REFERENCE.

name: ft_MButRel

return.name: <nBStat>
return.help: - an integer representing button release status 0 - None 1 - Left 2 - Right 3 - Middle

label: ft_MCOnOff( <nTop>, <nLeft>, <nBottom>, <nRight> )
documentation: Turn mouse cursur off if in specified region

arguments.label: <nTop>
arguments.documentation: , <nLeft> <nBottom> <nRight> are the four corners of the screen region in row and column coordinates.

name: ft_MCOnOff

return.help: NIL

label: ft_MCursor( [ <lState> ] ) -> lCursorState
documentation: Set the mouse cursor

arguments.label: <lState>
arguments.documentation: is a logical indicating whether to set the mouse cursor on. .T. - set mouse cursor on .F. - set mouse cursor off If omitted, no change is made to cursor state

name: ft_MCursor

return.help: A logical indicating the previous mouse cursor state.

label: ft_MDblClk( [ <nClick> [, <nButton> [, <nInterval> [, <nRow> [, <nCol>; [, <nTime> ] ] ] ] ] ] ) -> lIsDoubleClk
documentation: Return true if a double click was detected

arguments.label: <nClick>
arguments.documentation: is a numeric value.  If it is zero ft_MDblClk() will not check for the first press but rather will simply wait the specified period for a single press. This is useful if this routine is called from one which in turn responded to a button press. If it is not present or not equal to 0, then ft_MDblClk() will wait for two presses of the specified button.

arguments.label: <nButton>
arguments.documentation: is the mouse button number 0 - Left   Button 1 - Right  Button 2 - Middle Button [if applicable]

arguments.label: <nInterval>
arguments.documentation: is the interval to wait for the first click if requested and the time to wait for the second. If not present then defaults to 0.5 second.

arguments.label: <nRow>
arguments.documentation: is the row number for the mouse cursor location for a double click to be valid. If not present then the current position is taken as the valid location.

arguments.label: <nCol>
arguments.documentation: is the column number for the mouse cursor location for a double click to be valid. If not present, then the current position is taken as the valid location.

arguments.label: <nTime>
arguments.documentation: is an optional start time for the waiting period for the first click (of either one or two requested). If not given then the time is set at entry into this routine. This is useful when this routine is called from another routine which was called in response to a mouse click but needs to know if a double click has occurred

name: ft_MDblClk

return.help: .T. if a double click was detected.

label: ft_MDefCrs( <nCrsType>, <nScrMask>, <nCrsMask> ) -> NIL
documentation: Define the mouse cursor

arguments.label: <nCrsType>
arguments.documentation: is the cursor type. A value of 0 indicates the software cursor (the default) and a value of 1 indicates the hardware cursor.

arguments.label: <nScrMask>
arguments.documentation: is the screen mask for the software cursor or the first scan line of the hardware cursor. See the description for more information.

arguments.label: <nCrsMask>
arguments.documentation: is the cursor mask for the software cursor of the last scan line of the hardware cursor. See the description for more information.

name: ft_MDefCrs

return.help: NIL

label: ft_Menu1( <acBarNames>, <acOptions>, <acAction>, <acColors> [, <nTopRow> ], [ <lShadow> ] ) -> NIL
documentation: Pulldown menu system

arguments.label: <acBarNames>
arguments.documentation: is a character array containing the names to appear on the menu bar.

arguments.label: <acOptions>
arguments.documentation: is a multi-dimensional array with one element for each selection to appear on the pulldown menus.

arguments.label: <acColors>
arguments.documentation: is an array containing the colors for the menu groups.

arguments.label: <nTopRow>
arguments.documentation: is a numeric value that determines the row for the menu bar.  If omitted, it defaults to 0.

arguments.label: <lShadow>
arguments.documentation: is a logical variable.  If true (.T.) or omitted, it uses ft_Shadow() to add a transparent shadow to the each pulldown menu.  If false (.F.), the menu is drawn without the shadow. All arguments except nTopRow and lShadow are required.

name: ft_Menu1

return.help: NIL

label: ft_Menu2( <aMenuarray> [, <cColors> ] ) -> NIL
documentation: Vertical lightbar menu

arguments.label: <aMenuarray>
arguments.documentation: is an array of menu options, messages, and action blocks. Each element in this array is a nested array with the structure: element[ x, 1 ] = menu option element[ x, 2 ] = message to be displayed when option is highlighted element[ x, 3 ] = code block to be executed when option is selected

arguments.label: <cColors>
arguments.documentation: is a string containing colors for the prompts, in the same format as that returned by Set( _SET_COLOR ).  If not supplied, colors default to the current color setting.

name: ft_Menu2

return.help: NIL

label: ft_Metaph( <cName> [, <nSize> ] ) -> cMetaPhone
documentation: Convert a character string to MetaPhone format

arguments.label: <cName>
arguments.documentation: is the character string to convert

arguments.label: <nSize>
arguments.documentation: is the length of the character string to be returned. If not specified the default length is 4 bytes.

name: ft_Metaph

return.help: A phonetically spelled character string

documentation: Get the display page for the mouse pointer
name: ft_MGetPage

return.name: <nPage>
return.help: is the display page on which the mouse is currently being displayed

arguments.label: <nY>
arguments.documentation: is a variable that will receive the mouse Y position in virtual screen coordinates.  It must be passed by reference.

name: ft_MGetPos

return.help: an integer representing button status - 0 for no button pressed - 1 for left pressed - 2 for right pressed - 3 for left and right pressed - 4 for middle pressed - 5 for left and middle pressed - 6 for right and middle pressed - 7 for all three buttons pressed

name: ft_MGetPos

return.help: an integer representing button status - 0 for no button pressed - 1 for left pressed - 2 for right pressed - 3 for left and right pressed - 4 for middle pressed - 5 for left and middle pressed - 6 for right and middle pressed - 7 for all three buttons pressed

label: ft_MGetSens( <@nHoriz>, <@nVert>, <@nDouble> ) -> NIL
documentation: Get the mouse sensitivity parameters

arguments.label: <nHoriz>

arguments.label: <nVert>

arguments.label: <nDouble>
arguments.documentation: is the percentage of maximum sensitivity for doubling the mouse cursor's speed on the screen. PASSED BY REFERENCE.

documentation: Get mouse cursor row position
name: ft_MGetX

return.name: <nRowPos>
return.help: which is the row position of mouse in virtual screen coordinates.

label: ft_MGetY() -> nColPos
documentation: Get mouse cursor column position
name: ft_MGetY

return.name: <nColPos>
return.help: Column position of mouse in virtual screen coordinates

documentation: Decrement internal mouse cursor flag and hide mouse cursor
name: ft_MHideCrs

return.help: NIL

return.name: <aDHM_>
return.help: where: aDHM_[ 1 ] = cDAYS, aDHM_[ 2 ] = cHours, aDHM_[ 3 ] = cMinutes

label: ft_Min2Mil( <nMINUTE> ) -> cMILTIME

name: ft_Min2Mil

return.name: <cMILTIME>
return.help: character string of form hhmm, where 0<=hh<24.

label: ft_MSetSens( <nHoriz>, <nVert>, <nDouble> ) -> NIL
documentation: Set the mouse sensitivity parameters

arguments.label: <nHoriz>
arguments.documentation: is the sensitivity of the mouse on the horizontal axis. This value is the integer percentage of highest sensitivity and thus has a range of 1 to 100. The default value is 50 and at this setting about 3.2 inches of mouse movement will move the mouse cursor across the screen. If NIL, the current value is used.

arguments.label: <nVert>
arguments.documentation: is the relative sensitivity of the mouse on the vertical axis. The value is an integer percentage of the highest sensitivity and thus has a range of 1 to 100. The default value is 50 and requires about 2 inches of mouse movement will move from top to bottom of the screen.If NIL, the current value is used.

arguments.label: <nDouble>
arguments.documentation: is the relative sensitivity of the mouse to doubling the ratio of cursor movement to mouse movement. The default value is 50. If NIL, the current value is used.

name: ft_MSetSens

return.help: NIL

documentation: Increment internal cursor flag and display mouse cursor
name: ft_MShowCrs

arguments.label: <nType>

arguments.label: <nIRQ>
